definitions.definition: To revolve by turning over and over ; to move by turning on a horizontal axis ; to impel forward with a revolving motion on a supporting surface .
examples: To roll a wheel, a ball, or a barrel.
The child will roll on the floor.

definitions.definition: To wrap (something) round on itself; to form into a spherical or cylindrical body by causing to turn over and over.
examples: To roll a sheet of paper ; to roll clay or putty into a ball.
The cloth rolls unevenly; the snow rolls well.

definitions.definition: To bind or involve by winding , as with a bandage ; to enwrap ; often with up .
examples: To roll up the vase in bubble wrap.

definitions.definition: To drive , impel , or flow onward with a steady, wave -like motion.
examples: This river will roll its waters to the ocean.
The years roll on.

definitions.definition: To utter copiously, especially with sounding words; to utter with a deep sound; — often with forth, or out.
examples: To roll forth someone's praises ; to roll out sentences.

definitions.definition: To press, level, spread, or form with a roller or rollers.
examples: to roll a field ; to roll paste ; to roll steel rails.
The pastry rolls well.

definitions.definition: To move upon rollers or wheels.
To tumble in gymnastics; to do a somersault .
To leave or begin a journey ; sometimes with out .
examples: I want to get there early; let's roll .
OK guys, we're only down by two points. Let's roll !

subdefinitions.definition: To walk , especially leisurely or idly ; to stroll .
examples: Let's roll around town on foot and see the sights.

definitions.definition: To beat with rapid, continuous strokes, as a drum; to sound a roll upon.

To apply (one line or surface) to another without slipping; to bring all the parts of (one line or surface) into successive contact with another, in such a manner that at every instant the parts that have been in contact are equal.
To turn over in one's mind, as of deep thoughts ; to (cause to) be considered thoroughly.
To behave in a certain way; to adopt a general disposition toward a situation.
examples: I was going to kick his ass, but he wasn't worth getting all worked up over; I don't roll like that.

definitions.definition: To throw dice .

subdefinitions.definition: To roll dice such that they form a given pattern or total.
examples: If you roll doubles, you get an extra turn.
With two dice, you're more likely to roll seven than ten.

subdefinitions.definition: To create a new character in a role-playing game , especially by using dice to determine properties.
examples: I'm gonna go and roll a new shaman tonight.

definitions.definition: To perform an operation similar to a bit shift , but with the bit that "falls off the end" being wrapped around to the other end.
To rotate about the fore-and-aft axis, causing its sides to go up and down. Compare pitch , yaw .
definitions.label_groups: intransitive , aviation , nautical , of an aircraft or vessel

definitions.definition: To beat up ; to assault .
To (cause to) betray secrets or testify for the prosecution.
examples: The feds rolled him by giving him a free pass for most of what he'd done.
He rolled on those guys after being in jail two days.

definitions.definition: To be under the influence of MDMA (a psychedelic stimulant, also known as ecstasy ).
To (cause to) film .
examples: The cameras are rolling .
It's time to roll the cameras.

definitions.definition: To slip past (a defender) with the ball.
To have a rolling aspect.
examples: the hills rolled on

definitions.definition: To make a loud or heavy rumbling noise.
examples: The thunder rolled and the lightning flashed.

definitions.definition: To utter with an alveolar trill .
examples: Many languages roll their r's.

definitions.definition: To enrobe in toilet-paper (as a prank or spectacle).
examples: The kids rolled the principal's house and yard.

definitions.definition: To create a customized version of.
To engage in sparring in the context of jujitsu or other grappling disciplines.
To load ocean freight cargo onto a vessel other than the one it was meant to sail on.
examples: Containers will be rolled to another mother vessel.

definitions.definition: To briskly arpeggiate (a chord), typically in an upward motion.

main_definition: ( ergative ) To revolve by turning over and over ; to move by turning on a horizontal axis ; to impel forward with a revolving motion on a supporting surface .
secondary_definitions: ( ergative ) To wrap (something) round on itself; to form into a spherical or cylindrical body by causing to turn over and over.
( transitive ) To bind or involve by winding , as with a bandage ; to enwrap ; often with up .
( ergative , sometimes figurative ) To drive , impel , or flow onward with a steady, wave -like motion.
( ergative ) To utter copiously, especially with sounding words; to utter with a deep sound; — often with forth, or out.
( ergative ) To press, level, spread, or form with a roller or rollers.
( ergative ) To move upon rollers or wheels.
( intransitive ) To tumble in gymnastics; to do a somersault .
( chiefly US , Canada , colloquial , intransitive ) To leave or begin a journey ; sometimes with out .
( transitive ) To beat with rapid, continuous strokes, as a drum; to sound a roll upon.

( geometry ) To apply (one line or surface) to another without slipping; to bring all the parts of (one line or surface) into successive contact with another, in such a manner that at every instant the parts that have been in contact are equal.
( ergative ) To turn over in one's mind, as of deep thoughts ; to (cause to) be considered thoroughly.
( US , slang , intransitive ) To behave in a certain way; to adopt a general disposition toward a situation.
( dice games , intransitive ) To throw dice .
( programming ) To perform an operation similar to a bit shift , but with the bit that "falls off the end" being wrapped around to the other end.
( intransitive , aviation , nautical , of an aircraft or vessel ) To rotate about the fore-and-aft axis, causing its sides to go up and down. Compare pitch , yaw .
( transitive ) To beat up ; to assault .
( ergative , slang ) To (cause to) betray secrets or testify for the prosecution.
( slang , intransitive ) To be under the influence of MDMA (a psychedelic stimulant, also known as ecstasy ).
( ambitransitive , of a camera ) To (cause to) film .
( transitive , soccer ) To slip past (a defender) with the ball.
( intransitive ) To have a rolling aspect.
( intransitive ) To make a loud or heavy rumbling noise.
( transitive ) To utter with an alveolar trill .
( transitive , US ) To enrobe in toilet-paper (as a prank or spectacle).
( transitive ) To create a customized version of.
( transitive , martial arts ) To engage in sparring in the context of jujitsu or other grappling disciplines.
( intransitive , shipping ) To load ocean freight cargo onto a vessel other than the one it was meant to sail on.
( transitive , music ) To briskly arpeggiate (a chord), typically in an upward motion.
